titleStmt.title: Lipidome of the reef-building coral Acropora cerealis: Changes under thermal stress

affiliation.orgName: A.V. Zhirmunsky National Scientific Center of Marine Biology

analytic.title: Lipidome of the reef-building coral Acropora cerealis: Changes under thermal stress

biblStruct.note: Received 9 February 2021; Received in revised form 30 April 2021; Accepted 7 May 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Corals Lipidome Acropora cerealis Coral bleaching

abstract.p: Coral bleaching is caused by complete or partial loss of coral endosymbionts in response to increased sea surface temperature and solar radiation. A thermal stress leads to formation of reactive oxygen species resulting in a disturbance of coral cell membranes. Lipids are an essential component of cell membranes. The lipidome of the hard coral Acropora cerealis and its alteration under thermal stress were studied. The features of A. cerealis lipids were trace amounts of monoalkyldiacylglycerols, a high content of triacylglycerols with 18:3 and 22:6 fatty acids and а high content of ceramide aminoethylphosphonate. A short-term exposure of coral fragments at 33 • C caused significant changes in lipids. Among the storage lipids, the content of triacylglycerols decreased after 12-h exposure. Among the structural lipids, contents of ethanolamine-, choline-, and inositolglycerophospholipids decreased; the most pronounced changes were observed in the composition of phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylinositol after 24-h exposure.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Reefs are home to many benthic and pelagic marine organisms (Spalding and Grenfell, 1997). The structural basis of the reef is composed of reef-forming scleractinian corals (Scleractinia: Hexacorallia: Anthozoa) that have a hard calcareous exoskeleton. In recent years, episodes of mass coral bleaching have dramatically changed coral reef communities in the Indo-Pacific (Le Nohaic et al., 2017). Bleaching of reef-building corals results from disruption of symbiosis between the coral hosts and photosynthetic microalgal endosymbionts (zooxanthellae) caused by elevated seawater temperatures and/or solar radiation. This phenomenon leads to the death of the most coral organisms in the case of the complete loss of endosymbionts (VanOppen and Lough, 2018).

Lipids play an essential role in coral health and metabolism (Lim et al., 2017;Treignier et al., 2008). Neutral lipids (wax esters (WE), monoalkyldiacylglycerols (MADAG) and triacylglycerols (TG)) serve as a major energy source and storage depot, while polar lipids, primarily phospholipids (ethanolamine-, choline-, serine-, inositolglycerophospholipids (PE, PC, PS, PI), and ceramide aminoethylphosphonate (CAEP)), perform a structural function and constitute the basis of cell membranes. Several classes of glycolipids, such as sulfoquinovosyldiacylglycerol (SQDG), mono-and digalactosyldiacylglycerol (MGDG and DGDG) are essential components of biomembranes of the photosynthetic apparatus of zooxanthellae (Li-Beisson et al., 2018). The betaine lipid 1, 2-diacylglyceryl-3-O-carboxy-(hydroxymethyl)-choline (DGCC) is a component of algal cell membranes.

It is known that coral bleaching leads to changes in the lipid content and composition of the reef-building corals. Bleached Hawaiian hard corals Porites compressa showed 56% reduction of total lipid concentrations compared to non-bleached individuals, a proportional increase in concentrations of structural lipids, and a decrease in the level of storage lipids (Grottoli et al., 2004). The same changes in the lipid content and composition were demonstrated for Okinawan hard corals after a bleaching event (Yamashiro et al., 2005). An experimental short-term thermal stress caused in Acropora intermedia colony fragment a 65% decrease in the total lipid content compared to the control at 25 • C after 24-h exposure at 33 • C and a twofold reduction of structural lipids after 10-h and 24-h incubation (Imbs and Yakovleva, 2012).

An application of the lipidomic approach can significantly expand knowledge of the biochemistry of marine organisms. Lipidomics is a rapidly expanding research field that is focused on identifying of alterations in lipid metabolism and lipid-mediated signalling processes that regulate cellular homeostasis in healthy and diseased organisms (Han and Gross, 2003). A recent investigation of the influence of short-term experimental thermal stress on the soft coral Sunularia sp. lipidome (a profile of all lipid molecular species) has shown a number of significant changes in the content and composition of lipid molecular species (Sikorskaya et al., 2020). Nevertheless, knowledge on scleractinian lipidome is limited. Composition of phosphatidylcholine (PC) molecular species of Seriatopora caliendrum and the changes after herbicide contamination were shown by Tang et al. (2015Tang et al. ( , 2019. The WE content and the composition of gastrodermal cells and lipid bodies of the host coral across the diel cycle were determined in the lipids of the scleractinian Euphyllia glabrescens (Chen et al., 2017).

To expand knowledge on lipididomics of scleractinian corals, the present experimental study was focused on the lipidome of symbiotic tropical hard coral Acropora cerealis from Indo-Pacific. In addition, A. cerealis was exposed to a short-term experimental thermal stress. The dynamics of changes in total phospholipids (PL), glycolipids (SQDG + DGDG), in the storage lipid classes (WE and TG) and the variations in the content of individual molecular species of polar lipid classes (phospholipids and glycolipids) were studied during 24-h heat exposure.

div.head: Materials
div.p: For lipid extraction and thin-layer chromatography (TLC), hexane, benzene, chloroform, methanol, and 28% NH4OH of analytical grade were used; LC-MS grade hexane, 2-propanol, HCOOH, triethylamine (Sigma-Aldrich, USA) were used for HPLC. TLC was performed on readyto-use Sorbfil HPTLC-A silica gel plates, 10 × 10 cm (Russia). Triacylglycerols, glyco-, and phospholipid standards were purchased from Avanti Polar Lipids Inc. (USA). Tridecylpalmitate (analytical grade) was purchased from KNPO Diagnostikum (Russia).

div.head: Experimental design
div.p: Colonies of the hard coral Acropora cerealis were collected in the coastal waters of Vietnam (South China Sea) at a depth of 0.5-1 m during the low tide. Colonies were kept until use in a neutral-density shaded (*20% of sea surface irradiance) outdoor tank supplied with running seawater for no more than 2 days.

Colony branches of A. cerealis (totally 12 fragments) about 10-15 cm in length were left in aquaria containing 60 l of aerated, filtered seawater. The coral fragments were left for 24 h at 29 • C to recover from damage during fragmentation. Every day, all coral colonies were kept under a 12-h light-cycle at a light intensity of 200 μmol photons m − 2 s − 1 with white fluorescent lamps (National, FL20SS-N/18). Three fragments of hard corals were collected for the initial analyses (control). An automatic thermostat (±0.5 • C, IC Thermostat, EX-003) and aquarium heaters were used in the experiment, water temperature in aquarium increased from 29 to 33 • C over a period of about 4 h and then kept during 24 h at 33 • C. Three replicate colonies from aquarium were collected for the initial analyses of lipids at the 0-h exposure time. The coral fragments were taken for lipid analysis after 12 and 24 h of treatment.

div.head: Lipid analysis
div.p: Coral fragments at ~5 cm were crushed into 1-to 3-mm pieces. Total lipid extracts were obtained according to (Folch et al., 1957) with some modifications. Lipid was extracted by intensive homogenization in a chloroform/methanol (2:1 v/v) mixture (10 ml on 1 g coral tissues). The obtained homogenate was filtered, and the residue was washed in a chloroform/methanol (2:1 v/v.) mixture (10 ml), and then 10 ml chloroform. The extracts separated into layers by adding 20 ml of water. The lower layer was evaporated, and the total lipids obtained were redissolved in chloroform and stored at − 40 • C.

Amounts of phosphorus-contained total lipids were measured on a Shimadzu UV-1800 spectrophotometer (Japan) based on the amount of inorganic phosphorus upon oxidation in HClO 4 , as published previously (Vaskovsky et al., 1975).

Total lipids were separated by TLC in a chloroform-methanol-28% NH4OH-benzene (65:30:5:10) mixture, and the amounts of glycolipids were quantified by densitometry of TLC plates (Hamoutene et al., 2008;Imbs et al., 2015). DGDG and SQDG were quantified together because of their incomplete separation. Contents and structures of the molecular species of PL, glycolipids and betaine lipids were analyzed by a HPLC system with a high-resolution tandem mass spectrometer at positive and negative electro spray ionization (ESI). Analysis and identification of molecular species were performed as described earlier (Imbs et al., 2015(Imbs et al., , 2019Sikorskaya and Imbs, 2018).

Waxes in control and experimental samples were quantitatively analyzed by gas chromatography with flame ionization detector according to Bosh and Long (2017). Structures of wax molecular species in control samples were determined by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). Mass spectrometry data were interpreted as previously described (Urbanova et al., 2011;Sikorskaya and Imbs, 2018).

Amounts of TG and MADAG in total lipids of control and experimental samples were measured by densitometry of images of the analytical TLC plates in hexane-diethyl ether-acetic acid (90: (Hamoutene et al., 2008;Imbs et al., 2015), using the Sorbfil Videodensitometer software (Russia). After isolation of TG and MADAG fraction by preparative TLC in benzene, TG and MADAG molecular species of control samples were identified and quantified on a supercritical fluid chromatograph equipped with a light scattering detector and then on a triple quadrupole mass spectrometer at positive APCI (Sikorskaya, 2020).

div.head: Statistical analysis
div.p: Before use the raw data were examined of the homogeneity of variances (Levene's test) and the normality of the data (Shapiro-Wilk's test). Differences in the mean class lipid concentrations and lipid molecular species percentages were examined with a one-factor fully orthogonal analysis of variance (ANOVA). Significant differences between levels within the factors were examined post hoc with Tukey-Kramer HSD multiple comparison test. All statistical analyses were performed using STATISTICA 6 (StatSoft, USA). A statistical probability of P < 0.05 was considered significant. Values are reported as the mean ± standard deviation.

div.head: Acropora cerealis lipidome
div.p: The composition of storage lipids (WE, TG and MADAG), phospholipids (PC, PE, PS, PI, CAEP + lysophosphatidylethanolamine (LPE) and lysophosphatidylcholine (LPC)), glycolipids (MGDG, DGDG and SQDG) and betaine lipids (DGCC) were presented in Table 1. The predominant class of storage lipids was WE with the main 16:0/16:0, 16:0/14:0 + 14:0/16:0 and 18:0/16:0 molecular species (Table 1). Interestingly, a large amount of unsaturated molecular species of WE in two species of Acropora acuminate and A. cytherea were found (43.5% and 31.6% of the total WE, respectively) (Bosh and Long, 2017). It is possible that such a difference in the content of saturated and unsaturated of WE molecular species in a reef-building coral of the same family Acroporidae is associated with differences in nutrition and season sampling. Similar composition of WE was determined in lipids of scleractinian Euphyllia glabrescens (Chen et al., 2017) and in the soft coral S. siaesensis (Sikorskaya and Imbs, 2018).

The lipid extract contained a large number of molecular species of TG with acyl fragments 18:3 and 22:6, their total amount was 62.17% of the total TG. The TG profile of A. cerealis was significantly different from that in soft coral S. siaesensis (Sikorskaya and Imbs, 2018) and zoantharia Polythoa sp (Sikorskaya, 2020), in which the main TGs were saturated -16:0/16:0/16:0 and 16:0/16:0/18:0.

The determined glycolipids (SQDG, MGDG, and DGDG) are characteristic of zooxanthellae lipids (Li-Beisson et al., 2018). The composition of the molecular species of zooxanthellae lipids in A. cerealis is presented in Table 1. Molecular species of sulfated glycolipid SQDG contained saturated and monoenoic acids as in soft coral species (Sikorskaya and Imbs, 2018;Sikorskaya et al., 2020). MGDG and DGDG contained polyunsaturated FA 16:3, 18:3, 18:4, 18:5 and 20:5 characteristic of zooxanthellae (Joseph, 1979;Imbs et al., 2010;Imbs, 2014). A betaine lipid DGCC has been identified in A. cerealis (the content is not determined). The main molecular species of DGCC are 16:0/20:5, 16:0/22:6 and 18:0/28:7. DGCC are one of main lipids of non-photosynthetic membranes. They were found in Symbiodinium microadriaticum UTEX 2282, isolated from the jelly fish, Cassiopea xamachan (Leblond et al., 2015) as well as Durusdinium trenchii and Cladocopium C3 from Acropora valida (Rosset et al., 2019).

Compositions of PC and PE did not differ from that of reef-building coral Seriatopora caliendrum (Tang et al., 2017) and soft coral Sinularia siaesensis (Sikorskaya and Imbs, 2018). Diacyl PI molecular species with acyl fragments 22:4, 22:5 and 22:6 prevailed in A. cerealis (Table 1), which was similar to zoantharia Palythoa sp. (Sikorskaya, 2020).

The main molecular species of PS in A. cerealis lipids was 18:0/22:4. All detected molecular species of PS were in diacyl form, as in the lipids of hydrocorals Millepora platyphylla and Millepora dichotoma (Imbs et al., 2019). Only alkylacyl molecular species of PS were found in lipids of the soft corals S. siaesensis and Sinularia sp. (Sikorskaya and Imbs, 2018;Sikorskaya et al., 2020), alkylacyl and diacyl PS were detected in the lipids of the zoantharian Palythoa sp. (Sikorskaya, 2020).

The content and composition of CAEP in A. cerealis was significantly different from the values found in other coral species. A. cerealis lipids differed by a higher concentration of CAEP (19.57% of phospholipids), the CAEP content in soft coral S. siaesensis and in zoantharia Palythoa sp. were 8.3% and 11.4%, respectively (Sikorskaya and Imbs, 2018;Sikorskaya, 2020). The main molecular species of CAEP was 18:2(OH)b/16:0 with an additional hydroxyl group in the sphingosine base. In soft corals S. siaesensis and Sinularia sp., 18:2b/16:0 and 18:1b/16:0 prevailed (Sikorskaya and Imbs, 2018;Sikorskaya et al., 2020). In Palythoa sp., CAEP contained more than 60% of the methylated molecular species (Sikorskaya, 2020).

A characteristic trait of A. cerealis lipidome was the trace amount of MADAG in the lipid extract. It was noted in a number of studies that the content of MADAG in reef-building corals was lower than the content of TG (Imbs et al., 2010). For example, Acropora microphthalma contained 16.2% of TG and only 2.1% of MADAG in the total lipid content (Yamashiro et al., 1999 94). Other studies detected only WE and TG among nonpolar lipids in the scleractinian corals Seriatopora hystrix, Pachyseris speciosa, and E. glabrescens (Cooper et al., 2011;Chen et al., 2017). Unlike reef-building corals, soft corals contain higher concentrations of MADAG (Imbs et al., 2015;Sikorskaya and Imbs, 2018). It seems, a small amount of MADAG is a feature of hard corals.

Thus, the lipidome of the A. cerealis coral has been determined for the first time. Earlier, the lipidome of reef-building corals was partially studied (Tang et al., 2015(Tang et al., , 2019Chen et al., 2017). The lipidome of A. cerealis differs from lipid composition of other corals by a trace amount of MADAG, a high content of TG with 18:3 and 22:6 FA, and a high content of CAEP. The data obtained are of great interest and expand our knowledge in the field of lipidomics of marine invertebrates, including Cnidaria. Fig. 1 shows lipid contents determined in coral colony fragments after exposure to elevated temperature. Among storage lipids, WE do not significantly change during the experiment. The content of TG decreased after 12-h exposure to elevated temperature. The composition of TG molecular species did not change during experiment (Table S1). Structural lipids were most susceptible to changes when exposed to elevated temperature. After 24-h exposure, the phospholipid content decreased by 6 times. Reduced content of phospholipids was also shown previously for Acropora intermedia after 10-h exposure (Imbs and Yakovleva, 2012). On the other hand, soft corals Sinularia capitalis and Sinularia sp. showed no changes in phospholipid content after 36-h exposure to elevated temperature (Imbs and Yakovleva, 2012); (Sikorskaya et al., 2020). This significant reduction in phospholipids indicates that the structural lipids of A. cerealis are one of the main targets to heat stress. Therefore, we decided to evaluate changes in the content and composition of molecular species of phospholipids under heat stress.

div.head: The lipidome changes under thermal stress
div.p: Composition of molecular species of polar lipids (Table S2, S3) was studied in coral fragments of A. cerealis subjected to a short-term exposure to elevated water temperature (33 • C) in order to determine the main targets of the influence of heat stress on the coral lipidome. Fig. 2 shows a change in the content and composition of phospholipids after exposure to elevated temperature (0-h, 12-h and 24-h duration). Control samples did not differ significantly from 0-h samples. The most significant changes occurred after 24 h exposure at 33 • C.

The PE content significantly decreased after 24-h exposure in 3.5fold ( Fig. 2A). The molecular species of PE distinguished by the predominance of alkyl/acyl forms, the content of which significantly decreased as a result of exposure to heat stress, while diacyl molecular species of PE with 14:0, 16:0, and 18:0 acyl fragments appeared (Fig. 2B). Trace amounts of these molecular species were detected in A. cerealis lipids before thermal stress and after 12 h. As a result of the experiment, the content of diacyl PE increased from 2% to 66% of PE after 24 h exposure. The same effect in changing the composition of PE molecular species was observed in the soft coral Sinularia sp. exposed to elevated temperature (Sikorskaya et al., 2020). Biosynthesis of ether lipids requires specific enzymes in peroxisomes and in the Fig. 1. Dynamics of WE, TG, PL and DGDG + SQDG contents in A. cerealis after exposure to 33 • C for 24 h. All data points are mean ± SD, n = 3. Asterisks indicate a significant difference from the control (HSD test, P < 0.05). endoplasmatic reticulum (Dean and Lodhi, 2018). In the peroxisomes, alkylglycerone phosphate synthase (AGPS) forms the ether bond and changes the acyl chain for an alkyl group (Dean and Lodhi, 2018). The formation of alkenyl form of PE (plasmalogens) occurs in the endoplasmatic reticulum (ER) with the participation of plasmenylethanolamine desaturase (Braverman and Moser, 2012). The considerable change observed in the alkyl/acyl ratio in PE molecular species indicates a possible change in the activity of appropriate enzymes of peroxisome and the ER of A. cerealis at the short-term heat stress.

The main polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) in the PE of A. cerealis were 20:4n-6 and 20:5n-3. As a result of exposure to elevated temperature, the content of molecular species PE containing 20:5n-3 decreased from 21.4% to 0% after 24 h exposure. A decrease in PE and LPE containing 20:4n-6 was also observed from 74.5% to 43.6% and from 26.89% to trace amount, respectively (Fig. 2C). The decline PUFAcontaining PE and LPE and decrease of PE content indicate lipid peroxidation. Elevated temperatures cause oxidative stress in the zooxanthellae and coral cells, leading to accumulation of ROS (Weis, 2008). As it is known, PUFAs are the main target for ROS, leading to disruption of the cellular membrane and to formation of lipid peroxide (Lesser, 2006).

The PC content significantly decreased after 24-h exposure ( Fig. 2A) but the composition of main molecular species did not change (Table S2). The observed increase of LPC indicated PC degradation under thermal stress. PC reduction was also shown for Sinularia sp. after 36-h exposure to 33 • C (Sikorskaya et al., 2020). PC are one of the main structural lipids, that form membrane bilayers. Degradation of PC caused by activation of phospholipase A 2 in response to ROS formation (Beaulieu et al., 2014). Phospholipases A 2 cleaves glycerophospholipids at the sn-2 position with formation lysophospholipids and fatty acids; these enzymes were found in Cnidaria (Nevalainen et al., 2004). Accumulation of LPC can lead to increased permeability of cell membranes and their destruction (Law et al., 2019).

The PI content reduced from 3.4% to trace amounts after 36 hexposure. A significant PI reduction was shown for Sinularia sp. after 36h exposure to 33 • C (Sikorskaya et al., 2020). Thermal stress had a significant effect on the composition of the main PI molecular species (Fig. 2D). The content of the main 18:0/22:4 and 18:0/22:5 decreased from 56.6% to 27.1% and from 18.1% to 5.9%, respectively. The concentration of 16:0/22:6, on the contrary, increased from 10.3% to 58.2%. PI and phosphatidylinositol phosphates play a conserved role in cellular recognition, signalling and development (Rosic et al., 2015). Heat stress has previously been shown to cause an accumulation of inositol with corresponding declines in the turnover of inositol phosphates and phosphatidylinositol-based signalling pathways in the coral Acropora aspera (Hillyer et al., 2017). The significant reduction of PI in the bleached coral fragments also indicates on disturbance in signalling pathways. Control of phosphoinositide 3-kinases/protein kinase B (PI3K/AKT) signalling may act as part of one mechanism, which prevent both host apoptosis and autophagy of symbionts (Dunn et al., 2007). The disturbance of this signalling pathway caused by heat stress lead to initiation of the autophagic and apoptotic processes by host in relation to symbionts (Dunn et al., 2007).

The content and composition of PS did not significantly differ in bleached coral fragments ( Fig. 2A, Table S2). PS was also stable in experimental bleaching of soft corals Sinularia sp. (Sikorskaya et al., 2020). PS are asymmetrically distributed across the two sides of the membrane bilayer in mammalian cells. Normally PS is highly enriched on the inner side of the bilayer, but becomes exposed on the external side during apoptosis (Vance, 2015). The role of PS in apoptosis in coral cells needs future investigations. Our results showed that the experimental heat stress did not influence on content and composition of PS in A. cerealis lipids.

The composition of the main molecular species of CAEP has changed under the influence of elevated temperature ( Fig. 2E). There was a decrease in the concentration of 18:2b/16:0 from 25.98% to 15.21%, while the content of CAEP 18:2(OH)b/16:0 increased from 43.12% to 66.05%. The function of CAEP in marine organisms remains little studied. It is known that they are membrane constituents resistant towards the action of endogenous phospholipases (Mukhamedova and Glushenkova, 2000). The biological role of molecular species of CAEP needs further investigation.

As a result of heat stress, the content of thylakoid membrane lipids (DGDG + SQDG) decreased from 4.1% to 1.1% of lipid extract. Molecular species of MGDG with C 16 FAs decreased from 14.9% to 7.6% (Table S3). Because of heat stress, the biosynthesis of glycolipids in plastids broke and caused a decrease in the concentration of MGDG with C 16 FA (Li-Beisson et al., 2019). Among the molecular species of DGDG, no significant changes in concentrations were observed under the influence of elevated temperature (Table S3). The content of SQDG molecular species with monounsaturated fatty acids decreased after 24 h from 38.1% to 25.6%. Probably, an increase in the amount of saturated SQDG in A. cerealis lipids indicated a zooxantellae response to elevated temperature.

A number of studies showed a low ability of the genus Acropora to withstand elevated temperature (Loya et al., 2001;Penin et al., 2007). One of the factors of reduced resistance of A. ceralis to negative environmental factors is the expenditure of structural lipids during bleaching (Imbs and Yakovleva, 2012). The obtained results showed the significant changes in A. cerealis lipids under thermal stress. After 12-h exposure at 33 • C a decrease in TG and PL contents occurred but significant changes in the molecular species of TG and PL did not shown. A depletion of PE, PC and PI contents and an increase of LPC content were determined after 24 h exposure at 33 • C. Heat stress affected mostly molecular species of PE and PI. The obtained data indicate disturbance of lipid metabolism and the oxidative degradation of lipids in coral organism under a short-term heat stress.

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Composition of phospholipids (a) and molecular species of PE (b), LPE (c), and PI (d) and CAEP (e) after exposure (33 • C) to 0 h and 24 h. All data points are mean ± SD, n = 3. Asterisks indicate a significant difference from the control (HSD test, P < 0.05).

figure.head: Table 1
figure.figDesc: Content and composition of lipid classes and molecular species of lipids in A. cerealis.

row.cell: Molecular species (% of the lipid class)

row.cell: All data points are mean ± SD, n = 3.
